svg.title: Supply Chain vs. Supply Web - Resilience Through Interconnection
svg.desc: A side-by-side comparison showing the vulnerability of linear supply chains versus the resilience of interconnected supply webs. The left side shows a rigid straight line of suppliers vulnerable to disruption, while the right side shows a robust network of interconnected local and bioregional suppliers creating multiple pathways and resilience.

This comparison illustrates the strategic transformation from vulnerable linear supply chains to resilient regenerative supply webs:
Left Side - Linear Supply Chain (Vulnerable): Shows a rigid, straight-line progression: Raw Materials Supplier → Component Manufacturer → Assembly Factory → Distributor → Retailer → Customer. Each entity is represented as isolated boxes connected only to the next step in sequence. This linear structure demonstrates several vulnerabilities:
- Single points of failure: If any one supplier fails, the entire chain breaks down - Geographic concentration: Long-distance shipping and centralized production create disruption risks - Limited redundancy: No backup suppliers or alternative pathways when problems occur - Brittle efficiency: Optimized for cost and speed but fragile under stress - Power imbalances: Dominant players can exploit dependent suppliers - Vulnerability indicators show potential break points where disruptions cascade through the system
A disruption symbol (lightning bolt) demonstrates how a single failure point can break the entire chain, leaving the customer without products and the factory without inputs.
Right Side - Regenerative Supply Web (Resilient): Shows an interconnected network where the central factory connects to multiple local and bioregional suppliers who also connect to each other, creating a web-like structure with multiple pathways and redundancies:
Local Suppliers include community-based producers, local manufacturers, and bioregional resource providers, all within shorter geographic distances. These suppliers also connect to each other, creating industrial symbiosis where one's waste becomes another's input.
Bioregional Network shows suppliers organized around ecosystem boundaries rather than political borders, supporting both ecological health and supply resilience.
Multiple Connection Pathways demonstrate that if one supplier has problems, multiple alternatives exist. The web structure shows horizontal connections between suppliers, not just vertical connections to the factory.
Community Integration shows suppliers embedded in local communities with democratic governance and worker ownership, creating stability through community relationships rather than just market contracts.
Regenerative Practices are indicated throughout the web, showing suppliers who restore ecosystems, pay living wages, and build community wealth while providing high-quality inputs.
Resilience Features include: - Redundant pathways: Multiple suppliers for critical inputs prevent single points of failure - Local production: Shorter supply lines reduce transportation disruptions and emissions - Community stability: Local ownership and democratic governance create reliable partnerships - Ecological integration: Suppliers who restore rather than degrade ecosystems provide long-term sustainability - Economic circulation: Value stays within bioregional communities rather than extracting to distant shareholders - Innovation sharing: Suppliers collaborate on regenerative innovations rather than competing destructively
This supply web structure demonstrates antifragility - the network actually becomes stronger under stress because disruptions reveal new connections and innovations rather than causing system failure.
svg.text: From Brittle Efficiency to Resilient Partnerships
Brittle efficiency • Single points of failure
Regenerative Supply Webs: From Extraction to Regeneration
Building resilient partnerships that strengthen communities and ecosystems while ensuring reliable supply
